My bill ensures that Congress upholds the Constitution and protects the Presidency and our government from corruption. Our Founding Fathers identified principles important to the bedrock of our democracy; they included an anticorruption measure known as the Emolument Clause. Its inclusion emphasized their desire to preserve independence from external influence.    President-elect Trump has achieved great wealth and his investments span across the United States and dozens of foreign countries. The possibility of hidden influences will eclipse every action and decision Mr. Trump makes. There is no way to be sure of the full depth of Mr. Trump’s conflicts particularly with his continued refusal to release his tax returns, a key component of accountability provided by every President and presidential candidate since Richard Nixon.   The highest ranking employee in the Federal government is not exempt from the Constitution. Congress owes it to the American people to ensure that Constitutional principles are upheld in the interests of liberty. I call on Speaker Paul Ryan to bring my bill to the House Floor for a vote.

As President Donald Trump prepares to make big changes to our trade policy, my message to the American people is this: no matter who is President, I will never stop fighting for the middle class. Together we will work for fair trade deals that protect workers, the environment and basic human rights.  There are those who have fought for fair trade that protects American workers for decades, both inside and outside Congress, me included. (As seen below, in an excerpt from a 1996 rally with then-President Bill Clinton.) These efforts, particularly led by House Democrats, forced the TPP to fall apart last Congress.   Mr. Trump must now live up to his promise to the American people to institute fair trade principles in all the upcoming trade deals. Withdrawing from an already dead TPP is not enough. Trade fuels our economy, but Americans deserve a government that is looking out for them, not special interests.
